title: 114_s3160
content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or the "SOS Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or "SOS Act," defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "Department," "infraction," "Inspector General," and "intelligence community." The "Securing our Secrets Act" defines key terms including Inspector General as the official for the Department of State and Broadcasting Board of Governors, intelligence community as defined in the National Security Act of 1947, and Secretary as the Secretary of State. SEC. 3. USE OF NONGOVERNMENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS. Employees of the Department must use only Department-owned electronic communication systems for work-related communications. The Secretary must certify annually that all employees have access to these systems. The Secretary must certify annually to Congress that all Department employees have access to electronic communication systems. If certification cannot be made, a report must be submitted detailing employees without access, reasons for lack of access, steps taken to provide access, and measures for recording and reviewing work-related electronic communications. The Secretary of State may waive requirements for electronic communication recording for up to 10 employees if it's in the national interest. All work-related communications must still be archived appropriately. The Secretary of State can waive electronic communication recording requirements for up to 10 employees if it's in the national interest. Work-related communications must still be archived in accordance with the Federal Records Act. Waivers are valid for up to 180 days and can be reissued. Multiple waivers can be issued if justified to congressional committees. The Inspector General will develop an oversight plan within 90 days to ensure compliance with the waiver requirements issued by the Secretary for up to 180 days. Multiple waivers can be issued if justified. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SECURITY REVIEWS AND VIOLATIONS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, with information on responsible employees, violation dates, descriptions, compromised information, violated laws, and actions taken in response. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as unauthorized transfer of classified information, violated laws, actions taken in response (disciplinary actions, training), and justifications for not terminating employees with multiple violations in the past 10 years. The report is protected under the Privacy Act and cannot be made public. The report required under subsection (a) must not be made public and must be transmitted to prevent the dissemination of protected information under the Privacy Act of 1974. SEC. 5. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION SPILLAGE. SEC. 5 outlines the detection and prevention of classified information spillage, including training for officials, randomized sampling of emails, and accountability through audits. The Secretary appoints officials for training, who then collect random email samples to detect spillage. The Inspector General audits this work and reports findings to congressional committees. The Secretary must certify that all Department personnel with security clearances have completed emergency refresher training on handling classified information, including rules for electronic communication and derivative classification. The curr_chunk discusses various aspects of handling classified information, including derivative classification, safeguarding information, handling foreign government information, processing FOIA requests, challenges to classification status, and protecting classified information that has been disclosed without authorization. The curr_chunk addresses challenges to classification status and the protection of classified information that has been disclosed without authorization, emphasizing the need for personal commitment, resource allocation, and optimized record systems for handling classified information. The program established under this order commits necessary resources to implement programs for handling and protecting classified information, ensures agency records systems optimize sharing and safeguarding of classified information, designates a senior agency official to administer the program, and includes the management of classified information in personnel evaluations. It also includes penalties for violations and requires employees to certify their training and understanding of rules and procedures. The Secretary shall prioritize emergency refresher training for employees with security clearances at different levels, requiring a signed certification of understanding and compliance with rules and procedures for handling national security information. The Secretary may delay emergency refresher training for specific employees or groups for up to 30 days if critical foreign policy interests require it, with notification to congressional committees. "Applicable rules and procedures" include relevant Federal statutes and Executive Order 13526 requirements. The term "applicable rules and procedures" in this section refers to relevant Federal statutes, Executive Order 13526 requirements, other executive orders on classified information, the Foreign Affairs Manual, and Departmental guidance or regulations. SEC. 7. ENDURING TRAINING PROGRAM TO PREVENT MISHANDLING OF INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION. The Secretary must establish a training program for Department employees on preventing the transfer of classified information to unauthorized systems. SEC. 8. PLAN FOR REFORMING RESPONSE TO REQUESTS FOR INFORMATION AND INFORMATION ARCHIVING. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days for completing reforms related to training Department employees in identifying classified information and ensuring proper classification procedures. The plan must include procedures for classification determination of information from the intelligence community, training on archiving electronic communications, and annual affidavit requirement for document archiving by Department employees. The plan requires annual affidavits from Department employees certifying proper archiving of documents in accordance with relevant laws and regulations. The Inspector General will report on the Secretary's implementation progress within a year of the Act's enactment.
